communications.subject: Nevada Public Records Act Request: Nevada SoS noncitizen voting response
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Nevada Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any communications between employees of the Nevada Secretary of State's office and Pamela J. Bondi (pbondi@americafirstpolicy.com) or any other employees of the America First Policy Institute with an email address ending "@americafirstpolicy.com. Please search for records between April 14, 2024 and present date.

Please also search for communications to and from  employees of the Nevada Secretary of State's office containing the term "America First Policy Institute" from April 14, 2024 to present date.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Kira Lerner

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Trixie Mattel and UCLA
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any agreements between The University of California, Los Angeles and Brian Michael Firkus (Trixie Mattel) regarding their appearance on January 16th, 2024, including costs and other venue specific accommodations.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Kieran Dazzo

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: Inventory of hardware and software
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

A list of all active hardware and software procured by the City. I am looking only for software and device models/names/versions, not individual device owners or serial numbers. I would prefer the list be provided in a CSV or Excel format if possible.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rose Terse

communications.subject: RE: Washington Public Records Act Request #PDR_181
communications.communication:
Hello Megan,

Following the link you provided is showing that only a redaction log has been provided. If this is the case, I assume that you mean to claim that all responsive records are considered exempt by the City under RCW 42.56.240(4), which covers security information such as passwords, access codes, security plans, etc.

Are you claiming that even the knowledge of the city's usage of basic software, such as Microsoft Word or Outlook, would risk the security of the city? Because that could only mean to me that the City has set up a very insecure, perhaps negligent, security environment. In fact, other MuckRock requesters have been provided similar records from the City of Seattle (see https://www.muckrock.com/foi/seattle-69/seattle-police-itd-authorized-software-department-of-information-technology-101093/).

May I remind you that the Washington Public Records Act RCW 42.56.030 is to be "liberally construed and its exemptions narrowly construed". I respectfully ask that I be provided with the full breadth of the requested information and will be considering my options for asserting my rights under the PRA.

Thank you,
Rose

communications.subject: RE: Washington Public Records Act Request #PDR_181

Hi Rose,

Records responsive to PDR_181 Terse were reviewed and I have provided the responsive record and updated the exemption log with the correct citation. You may view and download the records here:

https://burienwa.box.com/s/ypjt8ozzloe3lzj99z5ecx282154z48f

The link will be available until 6/16/2024. Please let me know if you have any issues with accessing the records or link.

The City of Burien has completed its search for records responsive to public records request PDR_181 Terse and has provided you with all responsive records and an exemption log for any records that have been redacted or withheld. Your records request is considered fulfilled and is now closed. This is the City of Burien’s final response to your request.

This completes your request.

Thank you,

Megan Brehm
Deputy City Clerk

communications.subject: RE: Washington Public Records Act Request #PDR_181
communications.communication:
Hello Megan,

I see that the hardware inventory list has again been withheld in its entirety in your latest response. Again, I must reiterate from my last message that the security of City hardware cannot possibly depend on withholding the names of hardware such as computer monitors etc in the City's inventory. According to guidelines written by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), "[s]ystem security should not depend on the secrecy of the implementation or its components." (https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/Legacy/SP/nistspecialpublication800-123.pdf) On the other hand, there is a significant public interest to know what hardware the City has acquired with taxpayer money and how it is being operated.

If there is a particular device where even knowing of its existence would threaten City security, that device should be individually redacted rather than withholding the full file. I do not consider this response to be adequate and again ask that you provide the full breadth of the requested records.

Thank you,
Rose

communications.subject: Fw: [EXTERNAL] New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act Request: Water Asset Management funds correspondence
communications.communication:
Dear Records Requestor:


Your request for information from the New Mexico Educational Retirement Board was forwarded to me. In accordance with the New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act (IPRA), “a written request shall provide the name, address and telephone number of the person seeking access to the records and shall identify the records sought with reasonable particularity.” Section 14-2-8(C) NMSA 1978.


If you will provide me with your name and mailing address, we can begin the process of allowing inspection of the relevant records.


The Inspection of Public Records Act can be found at 14-2-1 through 14-2-12 NMSA 1978.


Thank you.


Amanda Olsen



Amanda Olsen, Paralegal
NM Educational Retirement Board

Dear Ms. Rock,

I am responding to your email yesterday requesting any additional info regarding the source of delays on this request. Please be assured that we make every effort to respond promptly to every request. However, we must also ensure that we are diligent and accurate in our reply. Thus, when obtained, all documents and emails must be reviewed. Additionally, we must rely on the state agency that controls the entire state email system to identify and provide the emails requested. As you can imagine, the process takes time.

As to an estimated response date, in our letter of August 1, 2023, we noted that we intend to respond by September 6, 2023.

Thank you for your patience and please feel free to contact me if you have further questions.

Respectfully,

[cid:image001.png@01D9C623.0D3F7D80]

Rebecca

communications.subject: ATTORNEY CLIENT PRIVILEGED - RE: [EXTERNAL] RE: New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act Request: Water Asset Management funds correspondence
communications.communication:
Dear Ms. Rock and Ms. Burns,

Thank you for your inquiry and please accept our apologies for the delay.

As Mr. Scroggins noted in his August 3, 2023 email regarding our projected response, we always try to be prompt.  But as you might guess, the request references a large number of records.  As he said, we must thoroughly review all records to identify and obtain the responsive documents from both external and internal sources.  It is a complex and time-consuming process.

I am confident that we will have documents ready to provide on or before the December 6th, 2023, date noted in our recent communication.

Thank you for your continued patience!
Regards,
Renee



[cid:image002.png@01DA121F.C2136CB0]

MuckRock - Julia Rock<https://nmgov-my.sharepoint.com/:f:/r/personal/renee_garcia_erb_nm_gov/Documents/MuckRock%20-%20Julia%20Rock?csf=1&web=1&e=4gwfSH>

As also discussed, we will require additional time to provide the remainder of the records.  We plan to provide additional documents on or before February 1, 2024.  Thank you again for your continued patience regarding this matter.
Regards,
Renee

title: FOIA Request: Cellebrite policies and procedures

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: FOIA Request: Cellebrite policies and procedures
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records:

I am seeking documents which are relevant to all hardware, software, products, and other services associated with contract 22-493ISP-OPERA-R-129875/B-31537. I am seeking:

Policies and Procedures: Any current policies and procedures that have been adopted for use of all hardware, software, products, and other services associated with contract 22-493ISP-OPERA-R-129875/B-31537.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

e

communications.subject: RE: [External] RE: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: FOIA Request: Cellebrite policies and procedures
communications.communication:
Please see the response that was erroneously sent to the incorrect email address on 05-16-2024; assigned FOIA #06221763.

Re: FOIR # 06221763 Supplemental Response

Thank you for writing the Illinois State Police (ISP) with your request for information pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), 5 ILCS 140/1, et seq. ISP acknowledges receipt of your narrowed FOIA request dated April 8, 2024.

ISP is providing the Standard Operating Procedure for Cellebrite.  The responsive records are attached.  ISP does not maintain the hardware, software, manuals, or training materials as those items are provided through Cellebrite’s website and accessed as needed.

You have the right to review by the Public Access Counselor (PAC) in the Office of the Attorney General (5 ILCS 140/9.5(a)). You may reach the PAC at:

            500 S. 2nd Street
            Springfield, Illinois 62701
            (877) 299-3642
            public.access@ilag.gov<mailto:public.access@ilag.gov>

You also have the right to judicial review under 5 ILCS 140/11.


Respectfully,

ISP FOIA UNIT
Office of the Director
801 South Seventh Street, Suite1000-S
Springfield, IL 62703

Pursuant to the Texas Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

All records on the arrest, incarceration and case against Preston Lee Finley. Falls County, TX.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Bernadette Feazell

communications.subject: Arkansas Freedom of Information Act Request: Solar for All - Arkansas Finance
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Arkansas Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

All electronic records of Becky Keogh with following keywords:
- solar
- EPA

The request should include emails (sent, received, BCC, and CC), email attachments, text messages, encrypted messages (such as Signal and/or WhatsApp etc.), messaging apps (such as Slack, Trello and/or Asana etc.), cloud based file storage and document systems (such as Microsoft One Drive, Google Drive, and/or Dropbox etc.), social media direct messages for professional purposes (such as Facebook and/or Twitter etc.) and any other electronic records. 

This request should search professional accounts and any personal accounts used for professional purposes.

Please include any administrative assistant(s) and chiefs of staff that may report to the named individual.

The timeframe of this public records request is between June 1, 2023 through October 31, 2023

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: DDoSecrets (National Security Agency)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records mentioning, describing or relating to Distributed Denial of Secrets, abbreviated DDoSecrets. 

DDoSecrets is a non-profit whistleblower site founded in 2018 for news leaks which is sometimes referred to as a successor to WikiLeaks and came to international attention for its June 2020 publication of police documents, known as BlueLeaks. 

You may limit the search to between December 2018 and the date the search is performed.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Emma North-Best

title: FOIL Request for Data Supporting COVID-19 Vaccine Efficacy for Holiday Season Health Protection

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: FOIL Request for Data Supporting COVID-19 Vaccine Efficacy for Holiday Season Health Protection
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

I am requesting access to records that support the statement made by State Health Commissioner Dr. James McDonald, as reported on December 6, 2023, in Spectrum Local News: “If you don’t want to be sick for the holidays, grab the COVID vaccine.” Specifically, I am interested in:

	1.	Any statistical data, studies, or reports from January 1, 2023, to December 6, 2023, demonstrating the effectiveness of the COVID-19 vaccine in preventing illness during the 2023 holiday season.
	2.	Information regarding the timeline for COVID-19 vaccine effectiveness, particularly in relation to the period between vaccination and development of immunity, in the context of the holiday season.
	3.	Comparative analysis of COVID-19 infection rates, hospitalizations, and fatality rates among vaccinated versus unvaccinated populations in New York State during the 2023 holiday season.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jackson Parker

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #23-12-146
communications.communication:
David Harvey, Esq.
Records Access Officer
Empire State Plaza, Corning Tower
Albany, NY 12237
health.ny.gov

Re: FOIL Request Acknowledgment (FOIL #: 23-12-146)

Dear Mr. Harvey,

I am writing in response to your acknowledgment letter dated December 12, 2023, regarding my Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) request (FOIL #: 23-12-146) for data supporting COVID-19 vaccine efficacy for holiday season health protection.

I appreciate your request for additional information to assist in identifying records responsive to my request. In this regard, I would like to point out that my request specifically referenced a quote from Dr. James McDonald, Commissioner of Health. Therefore, I suggest beginning the search for responsive documents with Dr. McDonald and his office, including any communications and materials presented to him regarding the efficacy of COVID-19 vaccines.

Furthermore, it is crucial to include records from external parties who have provided information to the Health Commissioner that influenced his public health recommendations. This includes, but is not limited to, data or studies that support the assertion that vaccination can prevent individuals from being “sick for the holidays,” especially considering the biological variability among individuals and the time required to develop immunity.

Given the public interest in understanding the basis for health recommendations made by state officials, I urge a thorough and expedient review of relevant documents. Please consider this letter as a clarification to my initial FOIL request, focusing on Dr. McDonald’s office and related external communications.

Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to your response and the timely processing of my request.

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #23-12-146
communications.communication:
Dear Records Access Office,

I am writing to follow up on my Freedom of Information Law request, numbered 23-12-146, initially submitted on December 7, 2023, and acknowledged by your office.

As the date of your anticipated response (January 11, 2024) nears, I wish to ensure that my request is being processed efficiently and to offer any necessary clarifications.

In addition to the previously specified information on the efficacy of the COVID-19 vaccine during the 2023 holiday season, I would like to emphasize the importance of including records from external parties. These records are crucial, as they have contributed to the Health Commissioner’s public health recommendations. Specifically, I am seeking data or studies provided by these external entities that support the assertion that vaccination can prevent individuals from being “sick for the holidays.” This request is particularly focused on understanding the biological variability among individuals and the time required to develop immunity post-vaccination.

My request encompasses:

Statistical data, studies, or reports from January 1, 2023, to December 6, 2023, demonstrating the COVID-19 vaccine's effectiveness.
Comparative analysis of infection rates, hospitalizations, and fatality rates between vaccinated and unvaccinated groups in New York State.
Records from external parties influencing the Health Commissioner's public health recommendations, including data or studies on vaccine efficacy in relation to individual biological variability and immunity development.

Given the public interest and the ongoing public health guidelines, timely access to this comprehensive set of information is essential.

Please inform me if any further details or clarifications are needed from my side to expedite the processing of my request. I appreciate your cooperation and look forward to your prompt response.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #23-12-146
communications.communication:
Dear Mr. Harvey,

Thank you for your continued efforts in processing my Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) request (Ref: 23-12-146) concerning data supporting COVID-19 vaccine efficacy for holiday season health protection. While I appreciate the complexities involved in such a request, the extended timeline for completion, now projected to be March 19, 2024, raises significant concerns.

The urgency of this request stems not only from its public health implications but also from the need to understand the basis for public health recommendations that seemingly do not account for individual biological variability. The statements made by public health officials, which prompted this FOIL request, suggest a one-size-fits-all approach to vaccine efficacy, which may not adequately consider the diverse responses of individuals to the vaccine.

Given the potential impact of these recommendations on public understanding and decision-making, it is imperative that any data or communications used to formulate these recommendations be made available promptly. Therefore, I request a rolling release of documents as they are identified and reviewed. This approach will facilitate timely public access to information that is crucial for informed discourse and decision-making.

I urge you to prioritize the release of any documents that have already been identified, even if the search and review process for the entire request is ongoing. The provision of this information in a timely manner is essential for maintaining public trust and ensuring that health recommendations are based on a comprehensive understanding of the data.

Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to a prompt response and the expedited release of the identified documents.

title: FOIL Request for Information on COVID-19 Tests and Masks Distribution to Schools (New York State Department of Health)

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: FOIL Request for Information on COVID-19 Tests and Masks Distribution to Schools (New York State Department of Health)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

1. All communications between the Governor's Office and/or the State Education Department and/or Boards of Cooperative Educational Services (BOCES) regarding the distribution of COVID-19 rapid test kits and N-95 and KN-95 masks to schools, dated from January 1, 2023, to the present.
  
2. Records of all requests submitted by school districts and BOCES for COVID-19 rapid test kits and N-95 and KN-95 masks, dated from January 1, 2023, to the present.

3. Inventory records detailing the quantities of COVID-19 rapid test kits and N-95 and KN-95 masks that have been delivered to each BOCES for distribution to school districts, dated from January 1, 2023, to the present.

4. Any and all guidelines, memos, or advisories issued by the Governor's Office or the New York State Department of Health (DOH) regarding the distribution of COVID-19 rapid test kits and masks to schools, dated from January 1, 2023, to the present.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jackson Parker

Records of all requests submitted by school districts and BOCES for COVID-19 rapid test kits and N-95 and KN-95 masks, dated from January 1, 2023, to the present.3. Inventory records detailing the quantities of COVID-19 rapid test kits and N-95 and KN-95 masks that have been delivered to each BOCES for distribution to school districts, dated from January 1, 2023, to the present.4. Any and all guidelines, memos, or advisories issued by the Governor's Office or the New York State Department of Health (DOH) regarding the distribution of COVID-19 rapid test kits and masks to schools, dated from January 1, 2023, to the present.The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.Sincerely,Jackson ParkerUpload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Fnew-york-state-department-health-4384%252Ffoil-request-for-information-on-covid-19-tests-and-masks-distribution-to-schools-new-york-state-department-of-health-152035%252F%253Femail%253Dfoil%252540health.state.ny.us&url_auth_token=AAAdRzX8ru6EX-17hVMaEygpuG4%3A1qiQ3S%3AKCk9168wcYdm7W7crry4EdeHRqbh7z31XZlwPJBrkm4

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #23-09-211
communications.communication:
Subject: Appeal for FOIL Request Denial - FOIL Request Number: 23-09-211

Dear Mr. Harvey,

I am writing to appeal the denial of access to records under the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) concerning my request dated September 15, 2023, regarding the distribution of COVID-19 tests and masks to schools (FOIL Request Number: 23-09-211).

Despite receiving extension notices, the most recent of which estimated a completion date of May 3, 2024, there has been a significant delay without the provision of requested records. This delay undermines the principles of transparency and accountability, especially given the public health implications of the information sought.

Pursuant to New York Public Officers Law §89(4)(a), I am appealing the implicit denial resulting from the failure to provide the requested records within the statutory timeframe. The ongoing delays fail to comply with the timely access envisioned by FOIL, and there has been no justification for such extensive delays that would outweigh the public interest in disclosure.

I kindly request a review of this decision and timely access to the requested records. If this appeal is denied, please provide a written explanation, including the statutory exemptions relied upon for denying access to these records.

Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to your prompt response.

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Ralph Bunche
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records mentioning, relating to, or generated as a result of inquiry or investigation of Ralph Johnson Bunche (August 7, 1904 - December 9, 1971). Proof of death is not required as his date of birth was over 100 years ago.

Please conduct a search of the Central Records System, including but not limited to the Electronic Surveillance (ELSUR) Indices, the Microphone Surveillance (MISUR) Indices, the Physical Surveillance (FISUR) Indices, and the Technical Surveillance (TESUR) Indices, for both main-file records and cross-reference records for all relevant names, individuals, agencies and companies at FBI Headquarters. Please also conduct a search for records at the Alexandria Records Center. If any potentially responsive records have been destroyed and/or transferred to NARA, then I request copies of the destruction or transfer slips as well as any other documentation relating to, mentioning or describing said transfer or destruction, to include but not be limited to confirmation that the Bureau has no other copies of said records. If previously released records are available, then I request a rolling release consisting of those records while additional records are located and processed for release.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Paul Galante

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: FOIA - FBI - O.J. Simpson
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

All records relating to or mentioning Orenthal James Simpson, commonly referred to as O.J. Simpson (July 9, 1947 – April 10, 2024) - Famous American football player and movie star, notable for his murder trial (see: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/O._J._Simpson).

Please conduct a thorough search of the Central Records System, including but not limited to the Electronic Surveillance (ELSUR) Indices, the Physical Surveillance (FISUR) Indices, the Microphone Surveillance (MISUR) Indices, and the Technical Surveillance (TESUR) Indices - for both main-file records and cross-reference records for all relevant names, individuals, agencies and companies. 

If any potentially responsive records have been destroyed and/or transferred to NARA, then I request copies of the destruction or transfer slips as well as any other documentation relating to, mentioning or describing said transfer or destruction, to include but not be limited to confirmation that the Bureau has no other copies of said records. If previously released records are available, then I request a rolling release consisting of those records while additional records are located and processed for release.

Please see the following news article highlighting the death of Mr. Simpson: https://abcnews.go.com/US/oj-simpson-former-football-star-acquitted-murder-dies/story?id=16354000

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

J Ader

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: OJ Simpson
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records mentioning, relating to, or generated as a result of investigation or inquiry into football player Orenthal James Simpson (July 9, 1947 – April 10, 2024). His death is widely-known and widely reported; as such, privacy concerns under FOIA Exemptions 6 and 7 are voided, as are any concerns under the Privacy Act. For example, you may find his ESPN obituary at the following link: https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/39920478/oj-simpson-dies-cancer-age-76-family-says

Please conduct a search of the Central Records System, including but not limited to the Electronic Surveillance (ELSUR) Indices, the Microphone Surveillance (MISUR) Indices, the Physical Surveillance (FISUR) Indices, and the Technical Surveillance (TESUR) Indices, for both main-file records and cross-reference records of both HQ and all field offices for all relevant names, agencies, organizations, companies and events including but not limited to those cited in the previous paragraphs and/or links as well as a cross-reference with the Southern Poverty Law Center to include any information provided by the SPLC. This request includes but is not limited to 137, 157, 176, 177, 183, 184, 188, and 214 files. If previously released records are available, then I request a rolling release consisting of those records while additional records are located and processed for release. 

If this request is unclear, please contact me to allow revisions rather than deny the request. Similarly, if the requested data are available only in part, please fulfill the portion of the request that is available rather than denying it in full. For example, notes or reports are available/subject to release but personal identifying information are not, reply with the report summary and omit sensitive information.

AtNight Media is a representative of the news media and is primarily engaged in the dissemination of information to the public.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Nik Hatziefstathiou

title: ChatGPT (New York City Department of Education)

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: ChatGPT (New York City Department of Education)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

Public reports show that ChatGPT is a major topic of conversation at American public schools: https://nbc-2.com/news/local/2023/02/15/students-at-cape-coral-high-school-accused-of-using-artificial-intelligence-to-cheat-on-essay/amp/

Therefore, I hereby request the following records:

1) All instructional materials, presentations and presentation materials related to ChatGPT. This includes A) any notes taken during meetings that discussed ChatGPT and B) Any other documents related to ChatGPT including internal documentation, public relations materials, and executive summaries.

2) Any memos or communications sent to schools, administrators, teachers, parents, or students that mention "ChatGPT."

3) Any case studies, enforcement actions, contracts, or other documents mentioning ChatGPT 

4) Any academic dishonesty policies that mention ChatGPT

5) To the extent possible, any emails and associated attachments that mention ChatGPT

To help limit the extent of the responsive documents, please limit search from Jan 1, 2023 through the time this request is processed. Please deliver these documents on a rolling basis as responsive documents are found. You can treat #5 (emails) as a separate request because I suspect there will be many more responsive documents there.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. It will be used in the course of reporting for Motherboard, VICE's science and tech site (www.motherboard.vice.com).

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jason Koebler

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Annatoyn NextEra
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any and all written or electronic communications, including email attachments, between Travis Annatoyn and any officials, lobbyists, representatives or other staffers affiliated with NextEra Energy, the renewable energy company. This request also seeks all written or electronic communications sent or received by Travis Annatoyn that contains one or more of the following key words or phrases: "NextEra", "MBTA', "bald eagles" and/or" golden eagles". This request seeks records produced since January 20, 2021. 

I am a reporter with The Guardian, The Nation and other outlets.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jimmy Tobias

communications.subject: Arkansas Freedom of Information Act Request: Beverage Agreement Request (Arkansas State University)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Arkansas Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any agreements related to beverage pouring, distribution or selling rights on campus and/or athletic facilities and venues.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Sonny Albarado, a citizen of Arkansas, in coordination with Kelly North.

communications.subject: FOIA Response - Sonny Albarado - Beverage Agreement Request (Arkansas State University)
communications.communication:
Sonny,

The requested pouring rights agreement for Arkansas State University is attached.

Please acknowledge receipt for my records.

Jeff


Jeff Hankins
Vice President for Strategic Communications & Economic Development
501 Woodlane, Suite 600 | Little Rock, AR 72201
Office: (501) 660-1004 | Fax: (501) 660-1010
www.asusystem.edu<http://www.asusystem.edu/>

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Freedom of Information Law Request for Records Related to Chief Keith Dworkin's Employment
communications.communication:
Request to Village of Millbrook Clerk:

Village of Millbrook Clerk's Office
35 Merritt Avenue
Millbrook, NY 12545

Subject: Freedom of Information Law Request for Records Related to Chief Keith Dworkin's Employment

Dear Public Information Officer,

I am writing as an investigative journalist under the provisions of the New York Freedom of Information Law (Public Officers Law §§ 84-90), seeking access to records related to the employment and compensation of Chief Keith Dworkin, who is currently serving as police chief in the Town of Fishkill and potentially in the Village of Millbrook.

Requested Records:

Digital Documents:

Emails, Memos, Reports, and Correspondence: All documents regarding Chief Keith Dworkin's employment status and duties as police chief in the Village of Millbrook.

Legal support: Buffalo News v. Buffalo Enterprise Development Corp., 601 N.Y.S.2d 480 (N.Y. App. Div. 1993) affirms the public's right to access records related to government contracts and expenditures.

Contracts, Agreements, and Job Descriptions: All documents pertaining to Chief Keith Dworkin's employment as police chief in the Village of Millbrook.

Legal support: Capital Newspapers v. Whalen, 605 N.E.2d 1344 (N.Y. 1992) supports the public's right to access records related to public employees' job performance and conduct.

Financial Statements, Reimbursements, and Disclosures: All records related to any additional compensation or benefits received by Chief Keith Dworkin from his employment as police chief in the Village of Millbrook.

Legal support: Gannett Co. v. City of Rochester, 29 N.Y.2d 97 (1971) confirms the public's right to access records related to government activities and decisions.

Performance Evaluations, Disciplinary Actions, and Commendations: All records regarding Chief Keith Dworkin's performance as police chief in the Village of Millbrook.

Legal support: Westchester Rockland Newspapers v. Kimball, 50 N.Y.2d 575 (1980) emphasizes the importance of public access to records concerning the actions of public officials and the operations of government.

Complaints, Investigations, and Resolutions: All records related to Chief Keith Dworkin's conduct as police chief in the Village of Millbrook.

Legal support: Department of Justice v. Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press, 489 U.S. 749 (1989) supports the disclosure of law enforcement records for public scrutiny.

Budget Cuts and Staffing Reductions: All records regarding any discussions or decisions about budget cuts, staffing reductions, or other financial adjustments made to accommodate the hiring or compensation of Chief Keith Dworkin as police chief.

Legal support: NLRB v. Robbins Tire & Rubber Co., 437 U.S. 214 (1978) demonstrates the public's right to understand the strategic operations of public authorities.

Legal Precedents and Public Interest Justification:

The requested information is of significant public interest, particularly concerning government operations and the ethical considerations of public officials. The release of these records will enhance public understanding and facilitate informed community oversight.

Fees and Document Delivery:

Please inform me of any potential fees associated with the processing of this request. I request a waiver of all fees as this disclosure is primarily in the public interest, contributing substantially to the understanding of government operations and is not for commercial purposes. I prefer to receive the documents electronically, via email or on a CD-ROM if electronic transfer is impractical.

Response Time and Contact:

I anticipate your response within the statutory timeframe prescribed by law. Should you require any clarification or have questions regarding this request, please do not hesitate to contact me at the provided phone number or email address.

Thank you for your attention and cooperation. I look forward to your prompt and thorough handling of this request, as dictated by applicable laws and regulations.

Sincerely,
Jordan Lassiter

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: FBI - Records on Robert Molaro
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

- All records and files, regardless of physical form, including cross-referenced documents and ELSUR records, concerning or mentioning Robert S. Molaro (June 29, 1950 - June 15, 2020), a former member of the Illinois House and Senate and a horse racing lobbyist, an obituary of whom was published in the Chicago Tribune on June 17, 2020 in an article titled "Former legislator, horse racing lobbyist Robert Molaro dies." A copy of this obituary is attached as a PDF and is located at the following link: https://www.chicagotribune.com/politics/ct-robert-molaro-obituary-20200617-fi2w4432bzhapjosw4smqe3tai-story.html.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Shreyas Gandlur

Supporting documentation **

Please be advised that efoia@subscriptions.fbi.gov is a no-reply email
address. Questions regarding your FOIA request may be directed to
foipaquestions@fbi.gov. If you have received a FOIPA request number, please
include this in all correspondence concerning your request. Please note eFOIPA
requests are processed in the order that they are received. If you have not
received a FOIPA request number, your request is in the process of being
opened at which time it will be assigned a FOIPA request number and
correspondence will be forthcoming.

** 

Upon receipt of your FOIPA request number, you may check the status of your
FOIPA request on the FBI’s electronic FOIA Library (The Vault) on the FBI’s
public website, http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on the ‘Check Status of Your
FOI/PA Request tool’ link. Status updates are performed on a weekly basis. If
you receive a comment that your FOIPA request number was not located in the
database, please check back at a later date.

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: CFTC: ChatGPT Chat Histories and Guidance
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. Any CFTC produced policies, memos, emails, or alerts regarding employee use of ChatGPT.
2. Any CFTC produced policies, memos, emails, or alerts regarding how ChatGPT either impacts or might impact CFTC's mission.
3. Chat histories of any all ChatGPT sessions conducted on Commodity Futures Trading Commission controlled devices between November 30th, 2022 and May 16th, 2024

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Robert Delaware

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Walker military personnel file
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Personnel file for Dr. Mary Edwards Walker.  She was born in Oswego NY on November 26, 1832 and died in Oswego NY on February 21, 1919.  She was a civilian contract surgeon in the Civil War, assigned to the Army of the Cumberland and later the 52nd Ohio Infantry.  She was awarded a Medal of Honor shortly after the Civil War.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Sherman McCall

communications.communication:

Thanks for your help, and let me know if further clarification is needed.

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request -- McCall (RR1R-24-43958)
communications.communication:
*Reply to: RR1R-24-43958-JD*

MuckRock News
DEPT MR 161682
263 Huntington Avenue
Boston, MA 02115

ATTN: Sherman McCall
via EMAIL: 161682-76223658@requests.muckrock.com

Dear Mr. McCall:

This is in response to your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request for a
copy of the personnel file for Dr. Mary Edwards Walker, Civil War contract
surgeon. Your request was forwarded from the Department of Veterans Affairs
and received in this office on May 28, 2024, and assigned case number
24-43958.

The National Archives and Records Administration (NARA) is the repository
for the permanent and historically valuable records of the United States
Federal Government, which includes those of the U.S. Congress, the U.S.
Supreme Court and federal court system, and the agencies and departments of
the Executive Branch. Our holdings are not organized by name or subject,
but are primarily arranged by the federal office or court that created and
maintained the records, and thereafter by various filing schemes depending
on the type of record or the particular function of the federal office or
court in question. Moreover, it is important to note that NARA does not
have a master name and subject index that identifies all documents
pertaining to a specific individual, organization, topic, or geographic
location.

With regards to your request, the Archives 1 Reference Branch in
Washington, DC, houses numerous records relating to the Civil War and
includes records relating to military service. However, we should note that
the War Department did not create any consolidated personnel files during
the Civil War, and as such, there is no personnel file for Mary Edwards
Walker. But we checked the Records of the Adjutant General’s Office (Record
Group 94) and noted the following records are available for Mary Edwards
Walker:

   - File in the series “Personal Papers of Medical Officers and
   Physicians” (PI-17 Entry 561; National Archives Identifier 655782
   <https://catalog.archives.gov/id/655782>) -- 221 pages
   - File W-2068-VS-1863 (Congressional Medal of Honor File) in the series
   “Letters Received by the Volunteer Service Division, 1861–1889” (PI-17
   Entry 496; National Archives Identifier 18573415
   <https://catalog.archives.gov/id/18573415>) -- 300 pages
   - File in the series “Case Files Relating to Corrections of Military
   Records, 1961–2005” (A1 Entry 814; National Archives Identifier 300358
   <https://catalog.archives.gov/id/300358>)
      - Box 4 in this series contains the transcript of the 1977
      proceedings of the Army Board for the Correction of Military Records
      regarding Walker’s Medal of Honor (National Archives Identifier
      18463647 <https://catalog.archives.gov/id/18463647>) -- 85 pages

A reproduction of all of the files referenced above are available for
purchase. Our current fee for paper-to-paper (or paper-to-digital images)
is $0.80 per page. The total number of pages for all three files is
approximately 606 pages, which would bring the total cost for a
reproduction to $484.80. To obtain copies of any or all of these records,
please email our office directly at archives1reference@nara.gov. In your
correspondence, please reference the case number as "RR1R-24-43958-JD."

Additionally, we also checked the Records of the Department of Veterans
Affairs (Record Group 15) and located a pension file (#SC 142,715) for Mary
Edwards Walker. A reproduction of this pension file is available for
purchase and can be ordered online using form NATF 85. Please submit your
request via the NARA website at the following address:

https://www.archives.gov/veterans/military-service-records/pre-ww-1-records.


Please note that the FOIA's fee and fee waiver provisions do not apply to
archival records. The fee statute, 44 U.S.C. 2116(c), does apply. It does
not authorize NARA to waive reproduction charges for individual requesters,
and our inability to grant a fee waiver does not constitute a denial for
the purposes of the FOIA.

Furthermore, please note that the records in Record Group 94 and Record
Group 15 that we noted above are open and available to the public and do
not require a FOIA request to access them. As such, you do not need to
submit a FOIA request to obtain copies or view them in person. And with
regards to the latter, you are welcome to visit our facility in Washington,
DC, to view the records in our research room. While appointments are no
longer required, we do encourage interested researchers in making a
research room room appointment. To do so, please click on the following
link: National Archives in Washington, DC (Research)
<https://www.eventbrite.com/o/national-archives-in-washington-dc-research-48144467593>.
Our DC building page can be found at: https://www.archives.gov/dc.

This completes the processing of your request. If you have any questions,
you may reach me via email at john.deeben@nara.gov.

We do not consider this response a denial under the Freedom of Information
Act because we were able to locate records pertaining to your subject and
have provided you with instructions on how to obtain reproductions. Since
the records cited above are open and available to the public, you do not
need to file a Freedom of Information Act request to access them. However,
if you are not satisfied with our action on this request, your options for
appeal and dispute resolution are outlined in the attached enclosure.

This concludes the processing of your request.

Sincerely,

JOHN P. DEEBEN
Archivist, Archives 1 Reference Branch
Archival Operations - Washington, DC
National Archives and Records Administration

**********

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: scanner <A1-405-HPLJ500MFPM525@nara.gov>
Date: Fri, May 24, 2024 at 11:28 AM
Subject: Incoming FOIA - McCall

communications.subject: Office of the Arizona State Treasurer  Secure Email Registration Confirmation
communications.communication:
Dear Russel,

Your registration with Office of the Arizona State Treasurer  Secure Email was completed successfully. Now that you've registered with Office of the Arizona State Treasurer  Secure Email, communicating securely is easy!

As you know, Office of the Arizona State Treasurer  Secure Email protects our confidential correspondences by using the same security technologies as internet banking when sending and receiving sensitive email messages. But you likely didn't know that this service allows you to do so much more than address security and compliance, or guarantee delivery of messages that prevent statements such as "I never received it".

Office of the Arizona State Treasurer  Secure Email includes a patented Delivery Slip - a powerful tool for users that provides many features for increased efficiencies and control over sensitive messages and attachments. It is found on the right side of  all secure message, both in this Secure Message Center and your desktop Microsoft Outlook program ('Enable with MS Office Outlook').

5 things you can do with the Delivery Slip

Here's just 5 things you can do with the Delivery Slip that you probably never thought possible with basic email:

1. Know what happens to your secure message once it's sent. Track and prove when a secure message and attachment is received, read, replied to, forwarded, deleted or printed.

2. Send jumbo files via email. Now you can simply attach that 100 MB file to a message without having to find an external service to share it.

3. Completely recall a secure message - and it works! Now you can instantly retract a secure message and attachment - even days or weeks after the recipient has read the message - resulting in the recipient's inability to access or read the recalled secure message.

4. Prevent a recipient from forwarding or replying to a secure message; or prevent a recipient from printing or saving a message or attachment.

5. Add extra security for ultra-sensitive content with 'For Your Eyes Only' by including an additional password required for the message or attachment to be opened by the recipient. Also prevents internal or external access by email delegates.

Learn more about the benefits of  Office of the Arizona State Treasurer  Secure Email unique features: http://www.appriver.com/

Thank you, and we're glad to have you as part of Office of the Arizona State Treasurer  Secure Email!

_________________

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Ivan Frederick Boesky (March 6, 1937 — May 20, 2024)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records mentioning, relating to, or generated as a result of investigation or inquiry into former financier and convicted insider trader Ivan Frederick Boesky (March 6, 1937 — May 20, 2024). His death is widely-known and widely reported; as such, privacy concerns under FOIA Exemptions 6 and 7 are voided, as are any concerns under the Privacy Act. For example, you may find his New York Times obituary at the following link: https://www.nytimes.com/2024/05/20/business/ivan-f-boesky-dead.html

Please conduct a search of the Central Records System, including but not limited to the Electronic Surveillance (ELSUR) Indices, the Microphone Surveillance (MISUR) Indices, the Physical Surveillance (FISUR) Indices, and the Technical Surveillance (TESUR) Indices, for both main-file records and cross-reference records of both HQ and all field offices for all relevant names, agencies, organizations, companies and events including but not limited to those cited in the previous paragraphs and/or links as well as a cross-reference with the Southern Poverty Law Center to include any information provided by the SPLC. My request includes but is not limited to 137, 157, 176, 177, 183, 184, 188, and 214 files. If previously released records are available, then I request a rolling release consisting of those records while additional records are located and processed for release.

If any part of these documents are exempt from disclosure, please be sure to review and release all reasonably segregable nonexempt portions of responsive documents, as the FOIA requires.

I request that I be properly classified as a media requester. I am an associate editor at Reason Magazine who has written numerous articles on topics of public interest for the Daily Beast, the Asia Times, Responsible Statecraft, the National Interest, America Magazine and the Armenian Weekly, and I am requesting these documents in an editorial capacity. Please contact me if you have any questions about my media status.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Matthew Petti

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: transgender policy - HUD
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any internal communications between employees up to and including the director which include the words "transgender" and/or "transsexual" and/or "transgenders" and/or "trannies". Please consider any electronic messaging, policy development documentation, legal communications between other US government agencies and handwritten notes to be responsive to this request.

Please also limit the scope of this request to dates between October 1, 2016 and September 21, 2019.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Emily Crose

communications.subject: FOIA Request
communications.communication:
Hello,


The attached letter is in reference to your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request dated and received on September 19, 2019.  You asked for a copy of any internal communications between Department of Housing and Urban Development employees up to and including the director which include the words "transgender" and/or "transsexual" and/or "transgenders" and/or "trannies."  Including, any electronic messaging, policy development documentation, legal communications, between other government agencies, and handwritten notes.


Please be advised that HUD will comply with your request to the extent permissible by law.  Any records not subject to an exemption will be forwarded to you promptly upon completion of the Department's search and review process.  However, your request is too broad and vague to be processed.  Asking for copies of internal communications between employees up to and including the director doesn't provide a narrow enough scope.  The Department performs electronic searches by custodial names, has many employees at HUD, and you haven't provided any HUD employee names in which to utilize for a search.  Also, you initially state, "internal communications" and then later state "communications between other US government agencies." You need to specify whose records you want, or, if you truly only want internal records.



Please clarify your request within 15 business days from the date of this letter.  If I do not hear from you within that time, your request will be withdrawn.  Please be advised that such an action will not preclude you from filing other requests in the future.  If you wish to clarify your request, please email your clarification to eugene.a.mcgirt@hud.gov<mailto:eugene.a.mcgirt@hud.gov> or submit it to the following address:



U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development

Office of the Executive Secretariat, FOIA Branch

451 Seventh Street, SW, Room 10139

Washington, DC  20410-3000



Attention:  Eugene McGirt
Telephone:  (202) 402-4315

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request: transgender policy - HUD
communications.communication: Please include in the scope of this request, any communications including the provided list of words both internally, and between the Executive Office of the President (EOP) and the Department of Justice.

communications.subject: RE: FOIA Request
communications.communication:
I received your updated request asking for "any communications including the provided list of words both internally, and between the Executive Office of the President (EOP) and the Department of Justice".

But, you still haven't provided any HUD employee names in which to utilize for a search.

The Department performs electronic searches by custodial names, has many employees at HUD, and you need to provide names (or program office) in which to search.

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request: transgender policy - HUD
communications.communication:
I'm curious how I might know the names of specific employees within HUD. I would start by asking for any emails involving the current Director of HUD (Secretary Dr. Ben Carson since we're dealing with explicit names...) or any of his direct deputies (whose names I'm baffled you'd expect me to know without any contextual information).

However, I would also like to see emails involving lower level employees as well. I've never been challenged to provide specific names to fulfill a broad FOIA request of a similar nature, so perhaps you would be able to advise me how I might be able to help you get specific names. Is there not a way for you to perform a keyword search of recorded messages for the keyword list provided? If no, what is the technical challenge that is causing this?

communications.subject: RE: FOIA Request
communications.communication:
HUD doesn't utilize a system that allows for a "keyword search of recorded messages for the keyword list [you] provided" unless it's connected to a custodian's name.

Most submitted requests of this nature indicate employee names in which to conduct a search.

Names are usually provided based on the requester having an idea of the parties involved.

It seems that communicating about this via phone would provide an easier opportunity for clarity than our current fax/email method.

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request: transgender policy - HUD
communications.communication: I don't have any idea of the parties that may be involved in policy development of this type and it's unreasonable for you to expect that I would have specific names of individuals involved in this kind of policy development without privileged information.

communications.subject: RE: FOIA Request
communications.communication: Ben Carson is the Secretary and Brian Montgomery is the Deputy Secretary.

communications.subject: RE: FOIA Request
communications.communication:
Your request asks for emails of HUD employees.  It requires utilization of the Department's eDiscovery tool for a search for responsive records.  The Department's eDiscovery tool is contracted with a third-party.  The system utilized by this contractor auto-assigns a collection date on a first-in-first-out basis, and is capable of collecting records for a set number of custodians per day.  As a result, the Department does not maintain direct control over the collection process and cannot alter the scheduled collection date for a particular request.

Given the high volume of requests for eDiscovery searches, the third-party system is operating at capacity with a significant backlog.  Once the record collection has been completed, responsive records will be delivered to the FOIA Branch for review.  At that time, we will work diligently to finalize your request as quickly as possible.

communications.subject: 19-FI-HQ-02010 STILL INTERESTED REPLY FROM REQUESTER NEEDED
communications.communication: Hello, Please, let me know, viaemail to me at your earliest convenience, whether or not you are stillinterested in receiving a response to your Department of Housing and UrbanDevelopment FOIA request 19-FI-HQ-02010. I have been reassigned to process this request due to the priorprocessor’s FOIA Branch departure. You must confirm via email atwilliam.d.smith@hud.gov to me within 10 business days from the date of thisnotice that you want to continue with your request. If you do not confirm thatyou are still interested in receiving a response to your HUD FOIA requestwithin that time, your request will be administratively withdrawn. Please beadvised that such an action will not preclude you from filing this or otherrequests in the future. Currently, along withthe present incoming FOIA requests, we are still working to complete your FOIArequest as well as all the other backlogged FOIA requests. Our effort is toprovide responses to FOIA requesters who are still interested inreceiving them. We must apply theDepartments’ first in and first out FOIA procedures, as there are many requestssurrounding each other.  However, if you are still interested, I assureyou that we will provide a response to your request as soon as possible. The Departmentapologizes for the delay in processing your FOIA request. HUD has experiencedchanges that have contributed to a tremendous backlog and extensive delays inthe ability to process incoming requests in a timely manner. We look forward to youremail response.

communications.subject: 19-FI-HQ-02010 STATUS UPDATE TO REQUESTER
communications.communication: Hello Ms. Crose, This is in response to your August 20, 2020, email for a status of your FOIA request 19-FI-HQ-02010. As was conveyed to you in the Department’sinitial acknowledgement letter, once HUD properly receives a FOIA request, theDepartment has 20 business days within which to make a determination on therequest unless unusual circumstances exist. Under unusual circumstances, HUDcan extend the 20-day time limit for processing a request. Currently, along with the present incoming FOIA requests, we arestill working to complete your FOIA request as well as all the other backloggedFOIA requests. In addition, y our request asksfor electronic communications and/or calendar entries of at least one HUDemployee. Your request requires utilization of the Department’s eDiscovery toolto search for responsive records. The Department’s eDiscovery tool iscontracted with a third-party that uses a system which auto-assigns acollection date on a first-in and first-out basis and is only capable ofcollecting records for a set number of custodians per day.  As a result,the Department does not maintain direct control over the collection process andcannot alter the scheduled collection date for a particular request. Given the high volume of requests for eDiscovery searches, the third-partysystem is operating at capacity with a significant backlog.  Once therecord collection has been completed, responsive records will be delivered tothe FOIA Branch for review.  At that time, we will work diligently tofinalize your request as quickly as possible. Your eDiscovery search requesthas been scheduled to begin October 22, 2020. Our effort is to provide responses to all FOIA requesterswho are still interested in receiving them. In doingso, w e must apply the Departments’ first in and first out FOIAprocedures, as there are many requests surrounding each other.  However,if you are still interested, I assure you that we will provide a response toyour request as soon as possible. Please, let me know, via email to me at yourearliest convenience, whether or not you are still interested in receiving aresponse to your Department of Housing and Urban Development FOIA request. You must confirm via email atwilliam.d.smith@hud.gov to me within 10 business days from the date of thisnotice that you want to continue with your request. If you do not confirm thatyou are still interested in receiving a response to your HUD FOIA requestwithin that time, your request will be administratively withdrawn. Please beadvised that such an action will not preclude you from filing this or otherrequests in the future. The Department apologizes for the delay in processing your FOIArequest. HUD has experienced changes that have contributed to a tremendousbacklog and extensive delays in the ability to process incoming requests in atimely manner and as stated, w e will work diligently to finalize yourrequest as quickly as possible. If you wish to modify your FOIA request for any reason at thistime, please send your request modification to me via my email address shownabove, at william.d.smith@hud.gov ,as soon as possible to enable the Department to initiate the process for anappropriate response to you. Also, you may contact the Office ofGovernment Information Services (OGIS) at the National Archives and RecordsAdministration to inquire about the FOIA mediation services they offer. The contact information for OGIS is as follows:  Officeof Government Information Services National Archives and Records Administration 8601Adelphi Road-OGIS CollegePark, Maryland 20740-6001 Telephone: 202-741-5770, toll free at 1-877-684-6448 FAX:202- 741-5769 Email:at ogis@nara.gov If you decide to appeal, your appeal should include copies ofyour original request and this response, as well as a discussion of the reasonssupporting the appeal. The envelope should be plainly marked to indicate that itcontains a FOIA appeal and be addressed to:  U.S. Department of Housing andUrban Development Attention:  FOIA Appeals Office of General Counsel Office of Ethics and Appeals LawDivision 451Seventh Street, SW, Suite 2130 Washington, DC 20410 Telephone:(202) 708-3815 Youmay also submit your appeal on line at: https://www.hud.gov/program_ offices/administration/foia/ foiaappealsor email at HUDFOIAappeasls@hud.gov .
